data.title: Studying at the University of Bristol
data.meta_description: International student guide to studying an undergraduate or postgraduate degree at the University of Bristol.
data.text:
Founded in 1876, the University of Bristol combines a proud tradition of academic excellence with an independent and forward-thinking spirit. Bristol has an international reputation for high-quality education and research, with the work of its staff and students resonating across the world. More than 25,000 students currently study at the University from over 150 countries.

The University offers a wide range of courses across its six faculties, including Arts, Engineering, Health Sciences, Life Sciences, Science, Social Sciences and Law. It is renowned for its research excellence, focusing on interdisciplinary research that addresses some of the world's most pressing challenges. Bristol has numerous research centres and institutes, including the Bristol Robotics Laboratory, the Cabot Institute for the Environment, and the Jean Golding Institute for Data Science and Artificial Intelligence.

The University of Bristol acceptance rate is 67%, and to increase your chances of success, you can seek assistance from SI-UK's team of UK university experts. We can help you submit a winning application. You can take the first step towards your academic journey by scheduling a free consultation with us today.

Why choose the University of Bristol?

1. Ranking and reputation

The University of Bristol is an esteemed institution acclaimed for its robust academic programmes and research achievements. It has consistently secured high rankings among universities worldwide and in the UK, currently placing 15th in the Times and Sunday Times Good University Guide and 16th in the Guardian University Guide. In the QS World University Rankings 2023, the institute is placed 61st globally, with several subjects in the top 100.

The University of Bristol's rankings in several subjects are quite astonishing, with many in the top 100 in the world, including Veterinary Science (16th), Anatomy and Physiology (29th), and Mathematics (74th). With an exceptional research track record, it has been ranked 5th in the UK for research according to THE analysis of the Research Excellence Framework and 61st in the world according to the QS World University Rankings.

2. Excellent graduate employment rates

The University of Bristol is one of the most sought-after universities by top UK employers and boasts highly employable graduates. In the QS Graduate Employability Rankings, Bristol was ranked 49th out of over 786 institutions surveyed worldwide. This was an improvement from its previous year's ranking of 58th, even though QS surveyed a record number of universities.

The Careers Service at the University provides a comprehensive range of resources, including advice on career options, work placements, courses on career planning, and assistance with crafting resumes, applications, and interview skills. Furthermore, the service organizes the New Enterprise Competition, a competition for student startups with a £35,000 prize, and administers the Bristol PLUS Award, the university's employability award, which recognizes students for their extracurricular achievements throughout their degree programme and offers a framework for reflecting on their acquired skills.

3. Fantastic international student experience

A meet-and-greet service is available for international students arriving by plane, train or coach, and the International Welcome Lounge helps new arrivals settle in. Students can celebrate cultural events, share experiences and connect with students from around the world through the University’s Global Lounge.

Students are assigned a personal tutor or supervisor to meet with regularly, and the Study Skills service can help with academic development. The University supports student well-being with services such as online peer support, the Student Counselling Service and the Multifaith Chaplaincy.

The student community at the University of Bristol is incredibly diverse, reflecting the multicultural and international nature of the city of Bristol itself. The university attracts students from all over the world and prides itself on being a welcoming and inclusive institution. The university has a range of initiatives in place to support and celebrate diversity, including the Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic (BAME) Staff Network and the LGBTQ+ Staff Network. A wide range of student-led societies and groups also cater to different cultural, ethnic, and religious backgrounds.

4. Scholarships Opportunities

University of Bristol scholarships are available for both domestic and international students. These scholarships are designed to provide financial assistance to students who would otherwise struggle to pay for their education and are offered across a variety of disciplines, including engineering, science, humanities, and social sciences.

A popular University of Bristol scholarship is the Global Excellence Scholarship, which is awarded to high-achieving international students with a strong academic record and who can demonstrate exceptional leadership skills. Other scholarships include the Vice-Chancellor's Scholarship, the Think Big Scholarship, and the Bristol Scholars Scheme.

5. Member of the elite Russell Group

The University is one of the 24 members of the research-intensive Russell Group. Bristol is also one of the original ‘red brick’ universities - six institutions founded in the major industrial cities of England.

6. World-leading Law school

The University of Bristol also has a world-leading Law School which is ranked 48th in the world (Times Higher Education World University Rankings for Law), 14th in UK (Times and Sunday Times Good University Guide ) and in the top 10 UK Law Schools for graduate prospects (IFS Study).

7. Guaranteed accommodation

The University of Bristol provides more than 5,000 residential places for undergraduate students and around 1,000 for postgraduate students. University accommodation is guaranteed for all new first-year international students who apply by the deadline (subject to conditions).

There is both catered and self-catered accommodation in student houses and halls, some of which are arranged as flats. A regular bus service connects the halls with the University and other parts of the city, and students living in University accommodation travel free.

8. Great location

The University of Bristol is situated in southwest England and has all the energy of a bustling urban metropolis, but with a friendly, relaxed atmosphere that will help you feel at home. Most University buildings are situated close together at the heart of the city, so you can enjoy everything Bristol has to offer. The city is perfect for exploring on foot or by bike and is home to over 400 parks and green spaces – proportionally more than any other UK city.

The University of Bristol location in Clifton is a sprawling area bordered by Tyndalls Parks Road to the north and Park Row to the south. The Grade I listed Royal Fort Gardens, a former estate of the Tyndall family, is the heart of the University of Bristol campus, overlooked by the impressive School of Physics in the HH Wills Building. The campus is characterised by a mix of architectural styles, from Victorian villas to the ultra-modern Life Sciences Building.

The campus offers excellent facilities, including the University of Bristol library, study centres, IT facilities, sporting facilities, cafes, and nearby cultural attractions. It is easily accessible by road, rail, and public transport. One can find an indoor sports centre, a health and fitness suite, and a sports medicine clinic on the campus. The University also boasts a sprawling 38-acre outdoor sports complex at Coombe Dingle in Stoke Bishop.
